title: Is it really that bad of an idea to form a Single Member LLC?
question: I noticed a single member LLC can basically do nothing after forming the LLC and the IRS will classify it as a sole proprietor for tax purposes. If you have no employees, you will not need a EIN (correct me if I'm wrong on any of this) and can use your sole proprietorship EIN or SSN for tax reporting.
answers:
An LLC does provide even a single member with limited liability, if the owner takes care to treat the entity as a distinctly separate legal thing, both from an accounting and legal standpoint, capitalize it adequately, etc. The most important factor in allowing a claimant to "pierce the corporate veil" is when an owner tries to use a corporate entity to defraud someone and an inequity results.

The following constitutes general information only. No legal advice is given. No attorney-client relationship is created.

Generally (though not always) it is better to obtain a separate TIN. When the LLC first starts out, most lenders will still require the owner to guarantee the debts of the LLC. However, after time, the LLC will establish its own credit rating based upon its TIN. At that point the LLC truly becomes beneficial as it can borrow without your guaranteeing loans to it.

In my opinion, the concerns expressed in the posts that you cited are, at best, overblown. In addition, I believe that you may have misunderstood the points made in those posts.

Let's assume that you have personal debts that result in your creditor owning or otherwise having rights to your membership interest in your LLC. That's unfortunate, but if you cannot pay your debts, you should expect creditors to go after whatever assets they can find to the extent permitted by law. Furthermore, I'm not sure there is a huge practical difference between owning you membership interest and having rights to the economic portion of that interest - either way, you don't make money from the LLC. Indeed, if your personal financial situation is perilous, starting a new business may not be the best thing to do, whatever legal form that business takes.

I believe that the tax treatment that you choose for your LLC (please see the first link below) should be based on a discussion with your tax advisor rather than some hypothetical feared event.

And the need to comply with applicable formalities to avoid "alter ego" problems exists any time you form an LLC or a corporation, not just in personal-financial-peril situations - please see the second link below (discusses corporations, but applies similarly to LLCs).
